resources.string: The Cathedral of Learning, otherwise known as the most beautiful building in the world, was built in the 1920\'s. Standing at 535 feet (163 m for those weird metric people), it is the tallest educational building in the Western Hemisphere, the second tallest university building in the world, and the second tallest gothic-styled building in the world. The Cathedral has 30 nationality rooms, 28 of which are used for classes. Each room was dedicated to a culture that influenced the growth of Pittsburgh at or around the time of the University's founding. According to audio experts, the main room of the Cathedral, known Common Room, reduces sound by using acoustical tiles as the stones between the ribs of vaulting. But if you were to ask any of the students, thats a load of mumbo jumbo.

Sennott Square, don\'t forget the two n\'s and t\'s, was built in the early 2000\'s and was the largest University of Pittsburgh building built since 1978. Quite the multipurpose building, Sennott contains 4 floors of offices and classrooms, large amounts of retail space, and both over and underground parking. It currently houses Pitt\'s College of Business Administration, Department of Psychology, and School of Computing and Information's Computer Science department. What many people don't know is that during Halloween time, it doubles as a scary maze! Participants are tasked with finding a classroom in the building while disgruntled students appear out of the depths of the mysterious networking lab. Only one person has successfully found their classroom since the mazes started in 2004.
